Charitable giving should be safeguarded against taxation among lower-class Americans. One way to do this is by making the charitable deduction more widely available. One option is to  move the deduction “above the line,” making it available to both itemizers and non-itemizers.

Rebuilding civil society will require capitalizing on the strengths of America’s associational life to address its weaknesses. One way of doing so is to reform policy so that less of the charitable giving of Americans is subject to taxation. 👇🏼 https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=C3424D5D-659B-456C-8520-2813CD5D02BF …

However, as our report “What We Do Together” illustrates, the U.S. is suffering from long-term declines in its associational life. “Our institutions of civil society have weakened and withered, and our relationships have become more circumscribed.”  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=82AEEDDA-B550-481E-BA31-9623B85A20D6 …

In other words, Americans have been able to support their communities because of their material success, and they have had to because no other institution could do so. Americans’ charity has allowed nonprofits and other voluntary institutions to play a central role.

Americans have impressed foreign observers with their altruism & commitment to social causes beyond themselves. Tocqueville was struck by how, in the absence of an aristocracy/government administration capable of improving their communities, Americans united to do so themselves.

The charitable deduction allows itemizers to deduct the value of their charitable contributions to qualifying tax-exempt organizations. But because itemizers tend to have higher incomes, the charitable deduction overwhelmingly goes to higher-income taxpayers. We can fix that ↓

A reformed charitable deduction would be a means of making our tax code fairer, a precautionary defense against one obstacle to civil society, and a step towards a renewal of America’s voluntary institutions.

Those who argue that but for government overreach, civil society would be flourishing, should be asking exactly which government policies need correction, and the charitable deduction should be high on the list.

Rebuilding civil society is no small task. In some cases it will require exploring unorthodox ideas and experimenting with new approaches. But it will also require evaluating the policies we already have in place to see how they could be improved.

Voluntary associations, which often comprise local chapters within a larger organization, have been losing ground to national, professionally run organizations. Formal membership in many associations fell from 75% to 62% from 1974 to 2004, the most recent year of available data. pic.twitter.com/iGEegBBTr7

Any portrait of American civil society would be incomplete without a diversity of voluntary associations. These local groups can have wildly different functions, ranging from Rotary Club to Little League to the Knights of Columbus. All provide tangible benefits.
